keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to five years to life in prison for first-degree rape convictions in Utah, stemming from two separate incidents in 2008.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 and used multiple aliases, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, to evade capture and flee the US.
He was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, and his identity was confirmed through distinctive tattoos recognized by hospital staff in Scotland.
The victim described the trauma of being raped and the financial and emotional exploitation she endured, emphasizing the need for accountability and safety.

Rossi has a history of evading legal accountability, including a prior sex offender registration failure in Rhode Island and fraud charges in Ohio.
The case underscores the dangers of flight risks and the importance of legal systems using DNA databases and international cooperation to track fugitives.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, to five years to life in prison for first-degree rape convictions from 2008, after he allegedly faked his death in 2020 and fled the U.S. using aliases such as Arthur Knight. Identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, Rossi was arrested in Scotland in 2021 when his tattoos, including a Brown University crest, were recognized by hospital staff. He had a history of evading legal accountability, including failing to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island and facing fraud charges in Ohio. The case underscores the importance of DNA database use, international cooperation, and accountability in cases involving violent crimes and flight risks. The victim, who testified about the trauma of being raped and financially exploited, emphasized the need for safety and recognition of the lasting damage caused.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
